properties.title: Blyth
properties.head: Newcastle
properties.repairable: Little frequented or haunted with traffic of merchants or merchandises.

properties.title: Sunderland
properties.head: Newcastle
properties.repairable: Little frequented or haunted with traffic of merchants or merchandises.

properties.title: Hartlepool
properties.head: Newcastle
properties.repairable: Hartlepool is very much in decay and yet mete to be continued for traffic, and that it hath been long in decay, and as we are informed by the occasion of the loss of 22 ships with their goods by stress of weather about 80 years past, as also by the great decay of the pier, and that it is necessary for the service of Her Majesty and Commonwealth of the country there adjoining to be repaired, the charges of the same so far as we can estimate not having sufficient artificers to entrust us therein will amount to the sum of 300 marks.
properties.inheritance: Custom House belonging to the Crown is presently in utter ruin and decay. There is an other house within the town of Hartlepool the site whereof more fit and commodious for the better service of Her Majesty than the other decayed house, and that it was of the late inheritance of the dissolved monastery of St Tagusses and as we are informed in lease to the Lord Scroope for 6 years yet to come of the yearly rent of 8s. We find the said house in decay and that �5 would repair it.

properties.title: Whitby
properties.head: Newcastle
properties.repairable: The pier of Whitby is in great ruin whereby the creek there is much in decay, and we think it needful to be repaired.
properties.inheritance: A house belonging to the town and in good repair is used by the customs without payment.

properties.title: Scarborough
properties.head: Hull
properties.repairable: In times past hath had ships of merchandise. But within this 30 years is much decayed aswell by the decay of their pier as by loss of their ships in the wars northwards. And the same creek of Scarborough as all merchants declare is mete to be maintained both for that it is the best and almost only succour for ships betwixt the mouth of Humber and Holy Island in all storms the winds being on the east or north or betwixt both And also for that the most part of this coast ling and haberdyne is there made, and for that purpose the inhabitants traveleth for bay salt & many times in storms strangers hath heretofore when the pier was maintained brought thither wines, hops, and other merchandises. Mete to be continued as well for the trade of fishing there used as for bringing of Newcastle coals to serve the country there, & especially for preservation of all ships that shall travel on this coast.
properties.inheritance: There is at Scarborough a house occupied by the Cusomer & his deputies as their Custom House which standeth in very convenient place to the water and is in convenient repair & estate, the inheritance thereof is in the Incorpration of that town.

properties.title: Bridlington
properties.head: Hull
properties.inheritance: Houses stand conveniently for the purpose of the Customs.

properties.title: Hull
properties.head: Hull
properties.inheritance: The Custom House is in good repair and standeth within the town not far from the water & convenient for that purpose, as the Customers themself confesseth; the same house doth belong to the Incorporation of the town of Kingston upon Hull.
properties.notes: The only port that serves all Yorkshire with merchandise inward and outward. All the merchandise that is either laded out or brought in either by merchants of York or others is only laded & unladed at Hull, except it be corn or coals, the cloth, lead & other merchandise laded by merchants of York be brought from York to Hull in lighters & there laded & so is the merchandise brought over by them unladed at Hull & carried up in lighters. Coal cometh to Scarborough and the other creeks to serve the country there which is a plain country lacking fuel. All the merchants' staithes in Hull join to the river or haven where the ships lie and there and from thence they lade forth and take in all their wares and merchandises; their staithes be very nigh their ships, and other place there is not to be lade nor unlade at for their dwelling houses do join to the haven as Thames Street doth to the river, and their quays or wharves be on the backsides of their houses, and as the Customers there confess the Custom of Hull what by increase of the traffic there and by the new Impost of wIne and cloth is at this day increased from 400 pounds to 2 thousand pounds or thereabouts, but this last year by reason of stay of merchants the same was diminished much.

properties.title: Grimsby
properties.head: Hull
properties.inheritance: Houses stand conveniently for the purpose of the Customs.

properties.title: Wainfleet Haven
properties.head: Boston
properties.repairable: Not mete to be continued for merchandise, but only for the supply of fuel.
properties.notes: A pore beggarlye markett Towne and wherein dothe inhabytte no merchaunt or other person that useth any trafique of merchantdrise'

properties.title: Boston
properties.head: Boston
properties.repairable: It is somewhat decayed by reason the most of the merchants of the Staple frequenting the said port inhabit the country and not the town, and therefore do not use the trade to bring in merchandise; for the wools they do carry out of this realm; And also by reason that there is few merchants inhabiting within the said port free of the house amongst the Merchant Venturers whereby the trade into Flanders is taken from them which is among the other a great occasion of the decaying of the said port and traffic to and from the same. One of the best and chiefest wharfs within the town, a common wharf, is in decay and ought to be repaired by those of the Steelyard in London who hath a house there, and some of their company did inhabit and trade both inward and outward, but now they let the house out.
properties.inheritance: The Custom House is the chamber of the gatehouse of the manor place of Hawlegarthe, which the mayor and burgesses of Boston claim to be theirs by purchase; they made a claim in the Exchequer Court for a reasonable rent, and it has recently be repaired at the expense of the Customs. Considered to be worth 20s p.a. or �20 purchase.
properties.notes: It is beautified with a fair haven and hath safe harbouring for ships and goods coming to the same and an apt place for the serving all the county of Lincolnshire as the counties of Nottingham, Derby, Leicester, and Northampton with wares and victuals.

properties.title: Kings Lynn
properties.head: Kings Lynn
properties.repairable:
The allegation of the mayor and other the inhabitants of the port town of Lynn, how and by what occasion the said port is decayed.
Imprimis they allege that in time past there was used much clothing in the said port town of clothes called Lynn Whitts, whereof the most part were conveyed on the seas as well by the inhabitants there as by merchants strangers who came for the same and brought in other merchandise the which clothing hath been of long time decayed by reason of the great mass of unwrought wools carried over by the Staplers, so as in the parts beyond the seas they practised there the making of such cloths themselves whereby the vent of the said Whitts decayed and aswell the people that were set on work thereby as the merchants trade of occupying the same did soon decay & diminish, and consequently the town fell to great ruin. And the wonted repair of merchant strangers is lately withdrawn by whom the town did utter great plenty of corn, which is one of the principallest merchandises of this port beside the said cloths.
They further allege that in time past they had free liberty to traffic with their cloths and other merchandise unto Flanders & the Low Countries without any impeachment, whereof now they be inhibited by reason of the Company of the Merchant Venturers who restraineth all men except such as be of the said company, or at least all other be driven to seek such corners & live in such fear of their straight orders as few have pleasure to traffic of the seas.
They also allege that the inhabitants of the said port in time past had great traffic into Iceland to their great benefit, the which they be now also inhibited by reason of the King of Denmark will not permit them neither to buy nor sell as at that time they did.
properties.inheritance: The Custom House belongs to the town, and is lent to the Crown officers without rent. It serves the purpose reasonably well. There is cost to be done to make the passage new up into it, glazing, and the gutters, costing no more than �20. The mayor and brethren are contented that Her Highness shall have it for ever by such assurance as her Majesty's Council can devise for 4 shillings of yearly rent & bearing the reparations, reserving to themselves the lower part which is the Condytt House of the said town.
properties.notes: Decayed and not so well frequented & haunted as it hath been in times past, but yet much better frequented than any of the rest of the creeks be. Other decayed creeks there be which we speak not of becasue we see no necessity to repair them. The west side of the town of Lynn is builded upon the waters side and all their warehouses & storehouses be opened upon the same so that they may receive & deliver wares & merchandises in & out of the same warehouses to the fraud of the Queen's Majesty if great attendance be not given by her Highness's officers; and as to any of the said creeks we find no such place of suspicion.

properties.title: Wells Next The Sea
properties.head: Kings Lynn
properties.inheritance: No Custom House is needed.
properties.notes: Of Lynn's four creeks, Burnham and Wells be the most frequented & haunted with merchandise, and as we think neither they nor any of the other rest may be spared for that they be necessary aswell for the bringing in of coal, salt, and fish, as also for the loading and transporting of grain out of those quarters which is the greatest commodity of that country by reason of the great plenty of the same there.

properties.title: Yarmouth,  Great
properties.head: Yarmouth
properties.repairable: Decayed 50 years ago by the death of a great number of inhabitants including merchants, following which the peir and other defences were not maintained. The mouth of the haven has been stopped by the violence of the sea casting in sand and gravel, causing ships to unload in the Thames or at sea; merchants are forced to send their wares to Norwich by carts . The decay is evident in the large ancient buidlings at Norwich, some of which are decayed and unoccupied. Inhabitants of Yarmouth used to be occupied in the Iceland fishing trade, and finding coastal trade subject to 'great charges & discouragement' they seek to live on the land by farming, handicrafts or other occupations. Nevertheless, great sums have already been spent on trying to mend the haven. Repair is very necessary, but no estimate of the cost can be made; the 'chief defence thereof is to be made by 2 great peirs in to the main Sea which is to be considered only by discrete and expert workmen'.
properties.inheritance: The Customer uses his own house.
properties.alternative_house: A house is already built in West Street 'against the crane or loading place' for the safe resort of strangers and others.
properties.value: 33s p.a., plus �6 13s 4d to make it fit for purpose
properties.notes: The only port for the city of Norwich, as also for the relief and help of the most part of Norfolk and Suffolk, by three great rivers descending 20 miles and more.

properties.title: Aldeburgh
properties.head: Yarmouth
properties.inheritance: The Customer's Deputy uses his own house, although a house is provided by the burgesses of both Orford and Aldeburgh within the town of Aldeburgh.
properties.alternative_house: The house at Aldeburgh is more convenient than Orford.
properties.notes: Serves Orford and Aldeburgh. Frequented mainly with wares appertaining to shipping and fishing, being but a fisher town.

properties.title: Orford
properties.head: Yarmouth
properties.inheritance: The Customer's Deputy uses his own house, although a house is provided by the burgesses of both Orford and Aldeburgh within the town of Aldeburgh.
properties.alternative_house: The house at Aldeburgh is more convenient than Orford.
properties.notes: Serves Orford and Aldeburgh. Frequented mainly with wares appertaining to shipping and fishing, being but a fisher town.

properties.title: Woodbridge
properties.head: Yarmouth
properties.inheritance: The Customer's Deputy uses his own house
properties.alternative_house: A house in the Roode Street should be purchased.
properties.notes: Extends to Woodbridge. More frequented than Dunwich and Orford Haven. Three quays at Woodbridge named the Lord's Quay (or common quay), Pooteys Quay, and Smythe's Quay, all within the space of a furlong; the latter two quays were erected with the consent of the lord of the manor of Woodbridge for the use of their owners only, and it is thought better that these be stopped for the better management of the customs.

properties.title: Harwich Haven
properties.head: Ipswich
properties.notes: We think it very mete & expedient for the good service of the Prince to have a storehouse at Harwich & the Customer  to have a deputy always resident there because that the said town of Harwich standeth at the mouth of the water that taketh his course to Ipswich and is of ancient time called Orwell Haven, which is of such depth before the town of Harwich as any ship may come in and out at a low water, & diverse and sundry times the ships and other vessels of foreign parties are driven to lie before the said town, sometimes for extremity of weather, sometimes of nexessity of victuals, and many times to make sale of such wares & merchandises as they have in freight; And because that there is neither the Customer nor his deputy resident in the said town of Harwich and there ships many times being of such burthen as they are not able to pass to Ipswich by the deacy of the haven, And yet if they were they must observe the tides which require sometimes a longer abode than they are able to suffer they are compelled to depart without making sale of any their said ware & merchandises to the great hindrance of the Queen's Majestry of her Custom and loss and prejudice to the country. And yet we think it not mete that the said storehouse at Harwich should receive or discharge any ware or merchandises but in such cases of necessity, and that for the causes ensuing: One is if it were understand to the enemy that the whole traffic of charging and discharging were at that place and that the whole substance and wealth of ware & merchandises aswell inward as outward remained there from time to time, & knowing that they might come in and out at all times at their pleasure, the town also lying in such an Andle, and so environed with water as there is no passage to the same by land but at one street so that if the enemies should approach they might easily enter, spoil, and fire the town before the country could come to the rescue thereof, unless the Prince should defend it continually with a garrison of men, which were more charge than gain; The other is it will be an utter decay to the Queen's Majesty's town and port of Ipswich and to the whole country adjoining a great trouble & unquietness of the rest of the country which now have their wares & merchandises discharged 7 or 8 miles within the land and then should be driven to make their carriage so much further from their ancient trade & dwelling places. Also, there is a house claimed to be the Duke's Grace's of Norfolk holden of her Majesty as of her manor there by the rent of 8d per annum which house will be very apt & commodious for that service, & is in much ruin & decay, the reparations whereof will cost by estimation �20, but what the charges of the purchase thereof will be we know not.

properties.title: Ipswich
properties.head: Ipswich
properties.repairable: Partly decayed and not so much frequented as heretofore it hath been, and so hath continued by the space of 20 years last past, the occasion thereof been diverse. First no great ship or vessel above the burden of 40, 50, or 60 tons came or may come any further upwards towards the port of Ipswich than Downham Bridge, where may ride a vessel of 100 tons. Also, the said stream is partly landed up by certain mills erected at Ipswich Town End, and so upwards to the head of this stream where, as we are informed, the salt water hath had his course at a full sea into the main land three miles, and hath repulsed the fresh water casuing it to swell six miles above Ipswich; and now the salt water is so strengthened by the said mill dams that it is stopped at Ipswich so that the said salt water at the flood can not have his full course up the river, as before the erecting of those mills it was accustomed thereby giving the fresh water such head & repulse as at the low ebb the violence thereof cannot drive & scour down all such sand, ooze, and other silt as the sea commonly at every flowing water bringeth up as in time past. Also all the rubbish, filth, and baggage of the whole town of Ipswish is not weekly carried by cart into the fields (as in London) and other well-ordered towns, but thrown into the streets & back lanes, & with every rain water washed into the haven, by which means the channel of the said stream lying as it doth even crookedly as an eel, is of late years very much impaired, which things as well for the better maintenance of the port as of that town is very needfull and requisite to be reformed & amended, the costs & charges whereof by estimation will amount to the sum of 1000 marks.
properties.inheritance: There is a Custom House belonging to the said port at the west end of the common warehouse of the said town, beneath under a loft, parcel & belonging to the said warehouse, which Custom House containeth in length 20 feet and in breadth 14 feet, and standeth directly over against the quay of that port, having a certain open gallery or walking place before the same of 9 feet wide, standing upon posts with rails for men to lean upon, and is sufficiently well-repaired at the charges of the bailiffs of the same town and so is to be continued. The rent thereof is by year to the bailiff and burgesses of the said town 20 shillings; and the residue of that storehouse contains in length 90 feet in breadth 20 feet.
properties.alternative_house: At Ipswich is a house more apt & commodious to be purchased of one Raynbow for a Custom House there for the better oversight of Her Majesty, the inheritance where of will cost [blank].
properties.notes: It is manifest unto us by examination and view of the creeks & places aforesaid [under the supervision of Ipswich] that ware and merchandises have been of late time & some of long continuance used to be taken in & discharged at many of the forenamed creeks & lading places, but for the better service of the Prince & benefit of the Country, we think them not mete so to be continued or suffered, but rather to be all damned & disallowed (Except Ipswich, Harwich, Colchester Hithe, Maldon, Brightlingsea, & Leigh), because at all the other places commonly wares, merchandises, victuals, and all other commodities of this Realm specially from & out of the countries adjoining Corn & victuals, merchandises & others have been and daily be transported into the parties of beyond the Seas & to all other ports & creeks within this Realm at all men's pleasures without the knowledge or consent of the Customers, Controllers, or Searcher, as well to the deceit of the Prince as also to the great lack and discommodity of the said country adjoining. Francis Jermye Esq hath a house standing upon the haven there very suspiciously, whereout diverse merchandises have been & may be conveyed from time to time without the assent or knowledge of any the Customers or other officers.

properties.title: Brightlingsea
properties.head: Ipswich
properties.notes: The Queen's Town, parcell of the Cinq Ports, which at all times hath been a lading place as well to transport merchandises into the parts beyond the sea as from port to port within the Realm, so is mete to be continued & the same is a place mete for the building of the Queen's Majesty's ships.

properties.title: Wivenhoe
properties.head: Ipswich
properties.notes: A lading place of the Earl of Oxford.

properties.title: Maldon
properties.head: Ipswich
properties.repairable: The creek of Maldon is in much decay by reason that the main channel thereof is dolven up and divided up into sundry parts, with sand and great quantity of sea ooze and shingle, whereby now the same runneth out of the old course. The wharves and quays with the crane there be altogether ruinated for want of reparations, which the lady Docer, Andrew Mychson, John Sother, and others , the owners of the same, should maintain at their proper charges. The charges of the ridding, escouring, and carrying away of the said shingle and sea ooze will cost by estimation �100.

properties.title: Leigh on Sea
properties.head: Ipswich
properties.notes: A very proper town furnished of good mariners where commonly tall ships do ride, which is a common & a special lading place of butter, cheese, all manner of grain, and other things.

properties.title: Queenborough
properties.head: Sandwich
properties.notes: Among the creeks which sometimes receive in and deliver out wares and merchandise� for the ease of the country it is thought mete [to] be maintained and used for transporting of corn, wood, and other commodities out of one part of the realm into another part, making their entries and taking cockets and making certificate to the next port or creek adjoining where the said officers be resident; � as to the transporting of wares or merchandise to or from beyond th seas to be utterly damned.

properties.title: Rochester
properties.head: Sandwich
properties.inheritance: The Custom House at Rochester is the inheritance of Thomas Mylles of Rochester, who is well contented to depart from the same to the Queen's Highness. The rent of the said house together with the mansion house wherein the Queen's Deputy dwelleth is �4, the reparations convenient.
properties.alternative_house: Nevertheless it it thought convenient that where there is in Rochester aforesaid a house called the Chantry House which served some time for two chantry priests belonging to the bridge of Rochester, and which house is now used by the Wardens of the said bridge at the Queen's will and pleasure, that the same house were very convenient for the Custom House of the said town for that it standeth very nigh the water and is of great strength, wherein all the officers may have convenient dwelling, and there is a fair wharf hard adjoining where all wares & merchandise may be landed.

properties.title: Faversham
properties.head: Sandwich
properties.repairable: The creek of Faversham is lately decayed by the inning of certain marshes next adjoining to the said creek, which may conveniently be holpen by Commission of Sewers.
properties.inheritance: The owner of the Custom House is not willing to part with it. Reparations convenient.

properties.title: Whitstable
properties.head: Sandwich
properties.notes: Among the creeks which sometimes receive in and deliver out wares and merchandise� for the ease of the country it is thought mete [to] be maintained and used for transporting of corn, wood, and other commodities out of one part of the realm into another part, making their entries and taking cockets and making certificate to the next port or creek adjoining where the said officers be resident; � as to the transporting of wares or merchandise to or from beyond th seas to be utterly damned.

properties.title: Broadstairs
properties.head: Sandwich
properties.notes: Among the creeks which sometimes receive in and deliver out wares and merchandise� for the ease of the country it is thought mete [to] be maintained and used for transporting of corn, wood, and other commodities out of one part of the realm into another part, making their entries and taking cockets and making certificate to the next port or creek adjoining where the said officers be resident; � as to the transporting of wares or merchandise to or from beyond th seas to be utterly damned.

properties.title: Ramsgate
properties.head: Sandwich
properties.notes: Among the creeks which sometimes receive in and deliver out wares and merchandise� for the ease of the country it is thought mete [to] be maintained and used for transporting of corn, wood, and other commodities out of one part of the realm into another part, making their entries and taking cockets and making certificate to the next port or creek adjoining where the said officers be resident; � as to the transporting of wares or merchandise to or from beyond th seas to be utterly damned.

properties.title: Sandwich
properties.head: Sandwich
properties.repairable: The port is more frequented that any creek or member of the same, nevertheless the haven of the said port is decayed by inning of certain marshes adjoining to the said haven, which is to be remedied by Commission of Sewers.
properties.inheritance: The Custom House is the inheritance of William Southake, Customer there, and it standeth very commodiously. The yearly rent is 20s. He is not willing to depart from the inheritance by reason it is a part of his own dwelling house.

properties.title: Dover
properties.head: Sandwich
properties.repairable: The creek of Dover is much decayed by the working of the sea which is not in man's power to help without great charges.
properties.inheritance: The Custom House is the inheritance of infants so that it cannot be purchased.

properties.title: Shoreham
properties.head: Chichester
properties.repairable: The creeks of Selsey, Arundel, and Shoreham are so decayed that they are unmete to be continued.

properties.title: Portsmouth
properties.head: Southampton
properties.repairable: Portsmouth Haven and Newport Haven in the Isle of Wight is now most frequented and haunted with the traffic of merchants and merchandises and be most mete and very necessary to be continued.
properties.notes: There are four store houses nigh the water side which as they have reported no merchants there and used any merchandises.

properties.title: Southampton
properties.head: Southampton
properties.repairable: The port and haven is as well able to receive and have the repair of all merchants and merchandises for the safety of their ships and goods as ever it was.
properties.inheritance: There is a part of a house wherein the Customers usually do keep their office in and is now called the Custom House of the said port of Southampton. It belongs to the town, and 40s rent is paid to the lessee of the town, and it is very commodious and in good repair. The house might be bought for �50 or hired for �3 per annum.
properties.notes: Southampton is more frequented and haunted with merchants and merchandises than any of the havens and creeks thereunto belonging now are, and yet the same not so much frequented with the traffic with merchants and merchandises as it hath been for yon space of twenty years last past, by reason that the port is not frequented and haunted as it hath been with the repair of the carracks of Genoa [Jeane], and other great ships of Venice within this twenty years did lade and unlade all their merchandises at the said port and now the Venetians since that time have made their repair to Margate [Mergatte] where they do unlade, not only to the great hindrance and decay of the inhabitants of the said Town of Southampton but also (as they say) to the great deceit and diminishing of the Queen's Majesty's Customs as well inward as outward. There are three store houses upon the West Quay there, that have been occupied (as we are informed) for the laying of cables, anchors, ordinance, and other furniture for the ships of the merchants there, and also sometimes for sea coals, which store houses be not at this present in the occupation of any merchants there.

properties.title: Lymington
properties.head: Southampton
properties.repairable: Decayed by reason of lading of the prince's timber out of the New Forest from thence to Portsmouth and to all the fortresses and castles within the county of Southampton, and into the Islands of Jersey, Guernsey, and Alderney, and that within the space of 28 years past, and that the same is very necessary to be repaired specially for the service of the Queen's Majesty and also for the Commonwealth of the whole county thereabouts and the Isle of Wight, and �40 will repair the same with timber.

properties.title: Poole
properties.head: Poole
properties.inheritance: The Customer rents his own house to be used by the Customs.
properties.alternative_house: There is a house in Poole that standeth very commodious for the Customhouse there; now in the occupation of one John Mallack by lease for 53 years, a part of which house called the over room containing 50 feet in length and 24 feet in breadth will be sufficient for the purpose of the Customs.
properties.notes: The port of Poole is most and best frequented of any place within the shire of Dorset, and is well and sufficiently maintained and repaired by the township of Poole. West Lulworth less frequented than Weymouth and Lyme.

properties.title: Swanage
properties.head: Poole
properties.goods_in: marble, stones, and paviours to be carried by water to London and elsewhere

properties.title: Weymouth
properties.head: Poole
properties.repairable: There is a jetty that is utterly decayed and fallen down which if it were new made and re-edified would be very beneficial aswell unto the Queen's Majesty in enlarging her Highness's Customs as also to the Commonwealth of the country thereabouts, for that the said creek standeth most commodious for all the said shire and great pity it were if it should noe be re-edified.
properties.inheritance: The [deputy] Customer occupied one little house for the purpose of the Customs.

properties.title: Bridport
properties.head: Poole
properties.goods_out: stuff made of hemp to be carried by water to Devon and Cornwall

properties.title: Lyme Regis
properties.head: Poole
properties.repairable: At Lyme there is a place of harbour for ships and other vessels that shall arrive there called the Cobb which is decayed, the reparations and continual maintenance whereof hath and will be so chargeable to the inhabitants there that they shall not be able to continue the same and thereby the said creek of Lyme will be utterly decayed for ever to the great diminution of the Queen's Majesty's Customs and to the great prejudice of the Commonwealth thereabouts, except it will please the Queen's Majesty to allow some yearly portion out of her Highness's Customs there as before now it hath been for the continual maintenance thereof.
properties.inheritance: A house is hired for the purpose of the Customs, and is very commodious for that purpose.

properties.title: Teignmouth
properties.head: Exeter
properties.repairable: Although Teignmouth hath been much decayed by tin work, yet it is able to harbour and receive ships of 80 tons. Yet it is not like to be continued albeit that sometimes fish and salt is landed there, and the repairing thereof will be such chrage as is not to be bestowed.

properties.title: Exeter
properties.head: Exeter
properties.repairable: Not only Exeter and Dartmouth but also the creeks thereunto belonging be decayed & not so much frequented & haunted with merchants and merchandises as they have been, and the same decay hath by little & little of long time crept in, the occasion of which decay by report of some is thought to be the late impost that is set upon cloths & wines, and the statutes forbidding wines to be brought in in aliens' bottoms, which is to be further considered by this honourable Court; furthermore the amendment of those decays are necessary, and these be further to certify that at this present the City of Exeter hath bestowed great charges in making of a haven or Convaye of wares by water to their City which if it sort to that effect that it is meant for no doubt it will be a great commodity to all the country, and might amend the said port of Exeter and the creeks adjoining thereto.
properties.inheritance: There is a Custom House in the Southgate Street in Exeter called the Queen's Custom House, which standeth very commodious for the service of her Highness there and is well repaired, the inheritance of the same house is belonging to the Church of Exeter. The rent that is yearly paid for the same is 60s by the year.

properties.title: Dartmouth
properties.head: Dartmouth
properties.inheritance: In Dartmouth there is a Custom House standing hard adjoining upon the haven wherein one John Plumley, deputy to John Peter Esq, Customer of Devon, dwelleth, the inheritance of the same house belongeth to Mr Carewe of Haccombe, the yearly rent thereof is 60s, and it is well repaired.

properties.title: Plymouth
properties.head: Plymouth
properties.inheritance: The Custom House is the inheritance of the Customer, Thomas Edmonds, and standeth very fit for the same purpose, and is very well repaired, but what yearly rent is paid or allowed ofr the same certainly we know not, but we are informed that the said Customer is allowed at the Queen's Majesty's hands upon his account for the house and others 40 shillings.

properties.title: Looe
properties.head: Fowey
properties.inheritance: Rent for the Custom House (which stands well for the purpose and well repaired) charged to the Customer of Plymouth.

properties.title: Fowey
properties.head: Fowey
properties.repairable: The port is greatly decayed and little frequented with strangers, but only supported with the inhabitants there and the dwellers thereabout, and yet more frequented that other creek thereunto belonging, and that the same port hath yearly decayed by the space of 30 years chiefly for that merchants dwelling in the country living upon their farms occupy there the trade of merchandise and may ford their wares better cheap than the inhabitants can do, and also the said town is charged with the maintenance of 2 castles and a blockhouse there, and have neither fee nor allowance for the same, nor any kind of liberty nor privilege, for as touching their anchorage, keelage, bushellage, and other commodities there appertaineth to the mayor and town of Lostwithiel being a town 4 miles distant from the said port.
properties.inheritance: There belongeth no Custom House to the port, but the house now used for the same is the inheritance of James Durlace gent, being well repaired and standeth very commodious and that there is 6s 8d yearly paid for the rent of the same.
properties.notes: There be diverse little fishing places or caves within the said County viz Polperro, Newquay, [?]St Jurran, [?]Perkeo'coke, Mousehole, and others where little boats of 3 or 4 tons do fish and discharge the same.

properties.title: Truro
properties.head: Fowey
properties.inheritance: Rent for the Custom House (which stands well for the purpose and well repaired) charged to the Customer of Plymouth.

properties.title: Penryn
properties.head: Fowey
properties.inheritance: Rent for the Custom House (which stands well for the purpose and well repaired) charged to the Customer of Plymouth.
properties.cu_deputy: William Grubbe, servant to Mr Kelligrewe

properties.title: Helford
properties.head: Fowey
properties.inheritance: Rent for the Custom House (which stands well for the purpose and well repaired) charged to the Customer of Plymouth.

properties.title: Padstow
properties.head: Fowey
properties.inheritance: Rent for the Custom House (which stands well for the purpose and well repaired) charged to the Customer of Plymouth.

properties.title: Penzance
properties.head: Fowey
properties.inheritance: Rent for the Custom House (which stands well for the purpose and well repaired) charged to the Customer of Plymouth.

properties.title: St Ives
properties.head: Fowey
properties.inheritance: Rent for the Custom House (which stands well for the purpose and well repaired) charged to the Customer of Plymouth.

properties.title: Minehead
properties.head: Bridgwater
properties.repairable: Decayed by a parocke which hath increased within the weir', which the inhabitants of Minehead are bound to repair by the Charter.
properties.inheritance: A house is rented by the Customer at his own expense.

properties.title: Bridgwater
properties.head: Bridgwater
properties.repairable: Decay at the end of the quay likely to be 'the utter ruin' 'if speedy remedy be not had'. Previously repaired by Nicholas Halswell (customs officer). Stone for repair to be taken from the old castle.
properties.inheritance: The Customer uses his own house.
properties.alternative_house: Half and acre of ground within the castle called the Castle Green; timber from Queen's Wood  to be used for building.
properties.notes: Busier than in times past.

properties.title: Bristol
properties.head: Bristol
properties.inheritance: No Custom House doth belong to the said port, but that the Customers do hire a house for that  purpose of one William Tucker of Bristol, draper, from year to year, which William Tucker hath an estate for term of years in the same, and the said Customers pay to him for the same house 46s 8d a year, and that the inheritance of the same appertaineth to Roland Okever of London, milliner, and that the same house standeth very aptly for the service of the Queen's Highness and is in good reparations, and that the same reparations is borne by the said William Tucker.
properties.alternative_house: There is no other house or place either where the port is, or where any of the places aforesaid be, that standeth more fit & commodious than the Custom House situate at the said port of Bristol, for that we suppose her customs and duties growing within the said creeks and other places will not be able to answer such charges as the prince shall be at in the erecting & maintaining of any other Custom House or houses.
properties.notes: Diverse persons do with their plowes bring corn, grain, leather, calfskins, victuals, and other commodities of this realm to boats, barques, and vessels lying at the banks of the said river of Severn at full sea, and there do lade the same into the said boats and vessels secretly in the night, and from thence do transport the same into diverse parts beyond the seas and to other ports and creeks within the realm without licence or answering of the Queen's duties.

properties.title: Whitehaven
properties.head: Carlisle
properties.inheritance: No Customs House; such customs, tolls, and duties as appertaineth the prince there is one Thomas Marcopp Esq Customer of the port at Carlisle & his deputy that yearly receiveth the same to the Queen's Majesty's use. Creek in the inheritance of Sir Thomas Chalynor.

properties.title: Workington
properties.head: Carlisle
properties.inheritance: No Customs House; such customs, tolls, and duties as appertaineth the prince there is one Thomas Marcopp Esq Customer of the port at Carlisle & his deputy that yearly receiveth the same to the Queen's Majesty's use. Creek in the inheritance of Henry Curwen Esq.

properties.title: Maryport
properties.head: Carlisle
properties.inheritance: No Customs House; such customs, tolls, and duties as appertaineth the prince there is one Thomas Marcopp Esq Customer of the port at Carlisle & his deputy that yearly receiveth the same to the Queen's Majesty's use. Creek in the inheritance of  John Senows Esq.

properties.title: Chester
properties.head: Chester
properties.repairable: It is well known that 'the great supportation of the City consisteth in merchandise', and it is the chief port for foreign imports, 'and being now finished will be the only succour'; the port has been fifteen years in the making and yet not finished, having already cost 2 or 3 thousand pounds.
properties.inheritance: The Customer sits at the Exchequer within the Castle. A separate Custom House exists for the collection of customs due to the City.
properties.notes: There are no other creeks to which vessels of any burthen can attend, only lighters and small boats which may unload at their owners' pleasure.

properties.title: Stockton on Tees
properties.head: Newcastle
properties.repairable: Little frequented or haunted with traffic of merchants or merchandises.

properties.title: York
properties.head: Hull
properties.inheritance: Houses stand conveniently for the purpose of the Customs.
properties.notes: Standing on the River of Ouse that falleth into Humber.

properties.title: Saltfleet
properties.head: Boston
properties.repairable: In decay for 20 years; not mete to be continued for merchandise, but only for the supply of fuel. Saltfleet  easier to repair than Wilgrip.

properties.title: Arundel
properties.head: Chichester
properties.repairable: The creeks of Selsey, Arundel, and Shoreham are so decayed that they are unmete to be continued.

properties.title: Carlisle
properties.head: Carlisle
properties.repairable: Lately part decayed & not so much haunted nor frequented with merchants & merchandises as afore time hath been, partly for that the subjects of Scotland and also our subjects of lawland toward Scotland hath no such repair nor access to the said port & city for merchandises as afore time they have had; Secondary, the decay of a bridge called Eden Bridge whereby the subjects had recourse and passage; And thirdly the subjects may have no course and traffic of merchandises to the City; And the said port and City is mete to be maintained.
properties.inheritance: There is no Customs House, but one Thomas Marcopp Esq is Customer appointed for the Queen's Majesty, who receiveth such tolls and customs pertaining to the Queen's Majesty there, and payeth yearly rent & farm for the same to the Queen's Majesty.
properties.notes: A dry port; mete to be continued for maintenance of the city & subjects there.

properties.title: Colchester
properties.head: Ipswich
properties.inheritance: There is but one Custom House belonging to all the creeks [of Ipswich] and that is at Colchester Hythe, and standeth commodiously enough for the service of that creek even right over & against the quay and crane there. Rent payable to the bailiffs of Colchester as to her Highness's Fee Farm of that town, which Custom House is at this present in good and sufficient reparations, and so is to be continued by the bailiffs of that town.
properties.notes: An ancient lading place. At Colchester Hythe is a certain warehouse erected of late viz within 6 or 7 years last past within one arrow shot beneath and from the crane to the seawards, where not long sithence as is declared & said merchandises & wares have been laden & carried in to the parties of beyond seas without the knowledge of any Customer or officer to the deceit of the Rpince & the decay of that town and therefore not to be suffered. More, there John Hunwick, Thomas Scott, Thomas Myche, __ Cock, John Fowle, ____ Beaste, Henry Pascall, William Hammonde, & ____ Lambert, merchants, have 7 several storehouses or warehouses standing likewise very suspiciously upon the shore side of that stream of the hythe of Colchester, from out of the which at all times of the day & night wares may be laden & discharged without knowledge of any of the officers of the Custom House.

properties.title: Cley
properties.head: Yarmouth
properties.inheritance: The Customer's Deputy uses his own house
properties.alternative_house: A house should be built or purchased in Cley near the loading place there.
properties.notes: Extends to the towns of Cley, Wiveton, and Snitterley, which are no more than 2 miles from the sea. More frequented than Dunwich and Orford Haven.

properties.title: Cromer
properties.head: Yarmouth
properties.repairable: A 500-foot wooden pier is decayed and carried away by the sea to the utter decay of the town and surrounding country, being part of the greatest tillage and increase of corn in Norfolk; all noble men and others used to make their provisions of grain here, but now have to use Cley and Yarmouth.

properties.title: Dunwich
properties.head: Yarmouth
properties.repairable: Impaired by the enclosure of marshland, preventing the scouring which used to cleanse the haven. Necessary for the enclosures to be reopened, because much of the town of Dunwich has been consumed by the sea but it remains liable for a large fee farm.
properties.inheritance: The Customer's Deputy uses his own house, although a house is provided by the burgesses of Dunwich within the Market House some distance from the haven.
properties.alternative_house: A house would be better situated at Walberswick.
properties.notes: Serves Dunwich, Walberswick, and Southwold. Frequented mainly with wares appertaining to shipping and fishing, being but a fisher town.

properties.title: Heacham
properties.head: Kings Lynn
properties.inheritance: No Custom House is needed.
properties.notes: Of Lynn's four creeks, Burnham and Wells be the most frequented & haunted with merchandise, and as we think neither they nor any of the other rest may be spared for that they be necessary aswell for the bringing in of coal, salt, and fish, as also for the loading and transporting of grain out of those quarters which is the greatest commodity of that country by reason of the great plenty of the same there.

properties.title: Newcastle
properties.head: Newcastle
properties.inheritance: Custom House belongs to the Town of Newcastle, and is in good repair, paid for at the expense of the Town.
properties.notes: More frequented and haunted with merchants and merchandises than any other creek belonging to it.

properties.title: Ravenglass
properties.head: Carlisle
properties.inheritance: No Customs House; such customs, tolls, and duties as appertaineth the prince there is one Thomas Marcopp Esq Customer of the port at Carlisle & his deputy that yearly receiveth the same to the Queen's Majesty's use. Creek in the inheritance of William Pennyngton Esq.

properties.title: Plymouth,  Stonehouse
properties.head: Plymouth
properties.notes: Used but with lighters and such small vessels as doe convey such wares as are laden and unladen at [Plymouth] and at Saltash, � not mete otherwise to be used.

properties.title: Milton
properties.head: Sandwich
properties.inheritance: The owner of the Custom House is not willing to part with it. Reparations convenient.
properties.notes: At the creek at Milton which is 5 miles distant from the sea there be standing upon the said creek between the said town of Milton and the sea two storehouses, one belonging to ____ Transham of Sittingbourne, the other belonging to John Norden, into which said houses corn and other commodities be delivered, and the Queen may be by them deceived as well by reason of the absence of the officers from that place as for the nighness thereof to the sea.

properties.title: Charmouth
properties.head: Poole
properties.notes: Among the places where there may be wares laden and unladed which if they were stopped would be no prejudice to the Queen's Majesty's Customes nor the Commonwealth.

properties.title: Selsey
properties.head: Chichester
properties.repairable: The creeks of Selsey, Arundel, and Shoreham are so decayed that they are unmete to be continued.

properties.title: Wareham
properties.head: Poole
properties.goods_in: diverse wares to be carried by water to the port of Poole
properties.repairable: It would be well re-edified so that a ship of 300 tones may come thither.
properties.notes: Formerly the chief port town of Dorset

properties.title: Aust
properties.head: Bristol
properties.notes: Wares and merchandises have of long time and yet be used to be taken in and discharged, and notwithstanding be not [among] the places appointed for that purpose, � by means of taking in and discharging of wares and merchandises in the said places not limited for that purpose, great conveyance of grain, leather, and other commodities is used to the great impoverishment of the country thereabout, and therefore the said places are not mete to have continuance, but some device and means to be used to let the coming in of vessels and boats thither, and notwithstanding the same places not to be dammed because they be places by the which the water avoideth out of the low countrys thereabouts and be places to land wood and other things that the inhabitants thereabouts carry and recarry from place to place.

properties.title: Frampton
properties.head: Bristol
properties.notes: Wares and merchandises have of long time and yet be used to be taken in and discharged, and notwithstanding be not [among] the places appointed for that purpose, � by means of taking in and discharging of wares and merchandises in the said places not limited for that purpose, great conveyance of grain, leather, and other commodities is used to the great impoverishment of the country thereabout, and therefore the said places are not mete to have continuance, but some device and means to be used to let the coming in of vessels and boats thither, and notwithstanding the same places not to be dammed because they be places by the which the water avoideth out of the low countrys thereabouts and be places to land wood and other things that the inhabitants thereabouts carry and recarry from place to place.

properties.title: Hanley
properties.head: Bristol
properties.notes: Wares and merchandises have of long time and yet be used to be taken in and discharged, and notwithstanding be not [among] the places appointed for that purpose, � by means of taking in and discharging of wares and merchandises in the said places not limited for that purpose, great conveyance of grain, leather, and other commodities is used to the great impoverishment of the country thereabout, and therefore the said places are not mete to have continuance, but some device and means to be used to let the coming in of vessels and boats thither, and notwithstanding the same places not to be dammed because they be places by the which the water avoideth out of the low countrys thereabouts and be places to land wood and other things that the inhabitants thereabouts carry and recarry from place to place.

properties.title: Oldbury
properties.head: Bristol
properties.notes: Wares and merchandises have of long time and yet be used to be taken in and discharged, and notwithstanding be not [among] the places appointed for that purpose, � by means of taking in and discharging of wares and merchandises in the said places not limited for that purpose, great conveyance of grain, leather, and other commodities is used to the great impoverishment of the country thereabout, and therefore the said places are not mete to have continuance, but some device and means to be used to let the coming in of vessels and boats thither, and notwithstanding the same places not to be dammed because they be places by the which the water avoideth out of the low countrys thereabouts and be places to land wood and other things that the inhabitants thereabouts carry and recarry from place to place.

properties.title: Kessingland Haven
properties.head: Yarmouth
properties.repairable: Decayed and stopped up by the sea within the past 40 years or more; to be continued only as a common drain.

properties.title: Minsmere Haven
properties.head: Yarmouth
properties.repairable: Decayed and stopped up by the sea within the past 40 years or more; to be continued only as a common drain.

properties.title: Thorpe Haven
properties.head: Yarmouth
properties.repairable: Decayed and stopped up by the sea within the past 40 years or more; to be continued only as a common drain.

properties.title: Northolle
properties.head: Boston
properties.repairable: Not mete to be continued for merchandise, but only for the supply of fuel.

properties.title: Southolle
properties.head: Boston
properties.repairable: Not mete to be continued for merchandise, but only for the supply of fuel.

properties.title: Wilgrip
properties.head: Boston
properties.repairable: In decay for 20 years; not mete to be continued for merchandise, but only for the supply of fuel.

properties.title: Fleet Haven
properties.head: Boston
properties.repairable: Not mete to be continued for merchandise, but only for the supply of fuel.

properties.title: Bournemouth
properties.head: Poole
properties.notes: Among the places where there may be wares laden and unladed which if they were stopped would be no prejudice to the Queen's Majesty's Customes nor the Commonwealth.

properties.title: Studland
properties.head: Poole
properties.notes: Among the places where there may be wares laden and unladed which if they were stopped would be no prejudice to the Queen's Majesty's Customes nor the Commonwealth.

properties.title: Chapman's Pool
properties.head: Poole
properties.notes: Among the places where there may be wares laden and unladed which if they were stopped would be no prejudice to the Queen's Majesty's Customes nor the Commonwealth.

properties.title: Encombe
properties.head: Poole
properties.notes: Among the places where there may be wares laden and unladed which if they were stopped would be no prejudice to the Queen's Majesty's Customes nor the Commonwealth.

properties.head: Poole

properties.title: Flower's Barrow
properties.head: Poole
properties.notes: Among the places where there may be wares laden and unladed which if they were stopped would be no prejudice to the Queen's Majesty's Customes nor the Commonwealth.

properties.title: Bowleaze Cove
properties.head: Poole
properties.notes: Among the places where there may be wares laden and unladed which if they were stopped would be no prejudice to the Queen's Majesty's Customes nor the Commonwealth.

properties.title: Walditch Hive
properties.head: Poole
properties.notes: Among the places where there may be wares laden and unladed which if they were stopped would be no prejudice to the Queen's Majesty's Customes nor the Commonwealth.

properties.title: Chideock
properties.head: Poole
properties.notes: Among the places where there may be wares laden and unladed which if they were stopped would be no prejudice to the Queen's Majesty's Customes nor the Commonwealth.

properties.title: Burton Bradstock
properties.head: Poole
properties.notes: Among the places where there may be wares laden and unladed which if they were stopped would be no prejudice to the Queen's Majesty's Customes nor the Commonwealth.

properties.title: Godlingstone
properties.head: Poole
properties.notes: Among the places where there may be wares laden and unladed which if they were stopped would be no prejudice to the Queen's Majesty's Customes nor the Commonwealth.

properties.title: Ringstead
properties.head: Poole
properties.notes: Among the places where there may be wares laden and unladed which if they were stopped would be no prejudice to the Queen's Majesty's Customes nor the Commonwealth.

properties.title: Hornsea
properties.head: Hull
properties.inheritance: Houses stand conveniently for the purpose of the Customs.

properties.title: Flamborough
properties.head: Hull
properties.inheritance: Houses stand conveniently for the purpose of the Customs.

properties.title: Filey
properties.head: Hull
properties.inheritance: Houses stand conveniently for the purpose of the Customs.

properties.title: Langstone Haven
properties.head: Southampton
properties.notes: There is one store house nigh the water side not used with merchandises.

properties.title: Dersingham
properties.head: Kings Lynn
properties.inheritance: No Custom House is needed.
properties.notes: Of Lynn's four creeks, Burnham and Wells be the most frequented & haunted with merchandise, and as we think neither they nor any of the other rest may be spared for that they be necessary aswell for the bringing in of coal, salt, and fish, as also for the loading and transporting of grain out of those quarters which is the greatest commodity of that country by reason of the great plenty of the same there.

properties.title: Burnham Haven
properties.head: Kings Lynn
properties.inheritance: No Custom House is needed.
properties.notes: Of Lynn's four creeks, Burnham and Wells be the most frequented & haunted with merchandise, and as we think neither they nor any of the other rest may be spared for that they be necessary aswell for the bringing in of coal, salt, and fish, as also for the loading and transporting of grain out of those quarters which is the greatest commodity of that country by reason of the great plenty of the same there.

properties.title: Skinburness
properties.head: Carlisle
properties.repairable: Not commonly used nor occupied with any traffic or trade of merchandise.
properties.inheritance: No Customs House; such customs, tolls, and duties as appertaineth the prince there is one Thomas Marcopp Esq Customer of the port at Carlisle & his deputy that yearly receiveth the same to the Queen's Majesty's use.

properties.title: Boustead Hill
properties.head: Carlisle
properties.repairable: Not mete to be continued for sundry causes.
properties.inheritance: No Customs House; such customs, tolls, and duties as appertaineth the prince there is one Thomas Marcopp Esq Customer of the port at Carlisle & his deputy that yearly receiveth the same to the Queen's Majesty's use. Creek in the inheritance of the Lord Dacre.

properties.title: Walton Mill
properties.head: Ipswich
properties.notes: Lading place where commonly small boats do lade at all times.

properties.title: Birch Mill
properties.head: Ipswich
properties.notes: Lading place where commonly small boats do lade at all times.

properties.title: Wrong Oak
properties.head: Ipswich
properties.notes: Lading place where commonly small boats do lade at all times.

properties.title: Coast of Holland
properties.head: Ipswich
properties.notes: Men may & do use to lade with ships & boats all the length of the coast of Holland.

properties.title: Dorefleet Mill
properties.head: Ipswich
properties.notes: Within the liberties of Brightlingsea.

properties.title: Alresford Creek
properties.head: Ipswich
properties.notes: Within the liberties of Brightlingsea.

properties.title: Brestoflete
properties.head: Ipswich
properties.notes: At East Mersey Nicholas Myddleton hath a storehouse or warehouse standing there upon the very side of the creek which was built but within 5 years last past, from out of which, as is informed, victuals and other things have been & commonly may be laden & discharged without the knowledge of any the officers aforesaid.

properties.title: Thornflete
properties.head: Ipswich
properties.notes: Within the liberties of Colchester.

properties.title: Strowde Mill
properties.head: Ipswich
properties.notes: Within the liberties of Colchester.

properties.title: Vange Hythe
properties.head: Ipswich
properties.notes: At Burnham in the hundred of Vange one John Shoke hath a house wherein diverse times, as is said, victuals have been conveyed without the knowledge of any the said officers.

properties.title: New Haven
properties.head: Ipswich
properties.notes: [Precise location not identified]

properties.title: Yealm
properties.head: Plymouth
properties.notes: Used but with lighters and such small vessels as doe convey such wares as are laden and unladen at [Plymouth] and at Saltash, � not mete otherwise to be used.

properties.title: Step Pill
properties.head: Bristol
properties.notes: Wares and merchandises have of long time and yet be used to be taken in and discharged, and notwithstanding be not [among] the places appointed for that purpose, � by means of taking in and discharging of wares and merchandises in the said places not limited for that purpose, great conveyance of grain, leather, and other commodities is used to the great impoverishment of the country thereabout, and therefore the said places are not mete to have continuance, but some device and means to be used to let the coming in of vessels and boats thither, and notwithstanding the same places not to be dammed because they be places by the which the water avoideth out of the low countrys thereabouts and be places to land wood and other things that the inhabitants thereabouts carry and recarry from place to place.

properties.title: Longmarsh Pill
properties.head: Bristol
properties.notes: Wares and merchandises have of long time and yet be used to be taken in and discharged, and notwithstanding be not [among] the places appointed for that purpose, � by means of taking in and discharging of wares and merchandises in the said places not limited for that purpose, great conveyance of grain, leather, and other commodities is used to the great impoverishment of the country thereabout, and therefore the said places are not mete to have continuance, but some device and means to be used to let the coming in of vessels and boats thither, and notwithstanding the same places not to be dammed because they be places by the which the water avoideth out of the low countrys thereabouts and be places to land wood and other things that the inhabitants thereabouts carry and recarry from place to place.

properties.title: Cone Pill
properties.head: Bristol
properties.notes: Wares and merchandises have of long time and yet be used to be taken in and discharged, and notwithstanding be not [among] the places appointed for that purpose, � by means of taking in and discharging of wares and merchandises in the said places not limited for that purpose, great conveyance of grain, leather, and other commodities is used to the great impoverishment of the country thereabout, and therefore the said places are not mete to have continuance, but some device and means to be used to let the coming in of vessels and boats thither, and notwithstanding the same places not to be dammed because they be places by the which the water avoideth out of the low countrys thereabouts and be places to land wood and other things that the inhabitants thereabouts carry and recarry from place to place. At Cone Pill, Gatcombe Creek, and Broadoak Pill be diverse storehouses and cellars by the which secret conveyance of grain, leather, and other commodities is used, which storehouses and cellars were very expedient to be subverted and taken away, for that both the Queen's Majesty is thereby deceived of her Custom and duties, and the countrys thereabouts much damnified and hurt.

properties.title: Gatcombe Creek
properties.head: Bristol
properties.notes: Although among the six quays most frequented and haunted with traffic of merchants and merchandises, it 'lieth so covert upon the [Severne] that great conveyance of grain, leather, and other commodities prohibited to be transported beyond the seas is used there to the great hurt and discommodity of the country thereabout, & to the great advancement of the prices of grain, leather, and other commodities aforesaid. At Cone Pill, Gatcombe Creek, and Broadoak Pill be diverse storehouses and cellars by the which secret conveyance of grain, leather, and other commodities is used, which storehouses and cellars were very expedient to be subverted and taken away, for that both the Queen's Majesty is thereby deceived of her Custom and duties, and the countrys thereabouts much damnified and hurt.

properties.title: Kingsdown
properties.head: Sandwich
properties.notes: Among the creeks which sometimes receive in and deliver out wares and merchandise� for the ease of the country it is thought mete [to] be maintained and used for transporting of corn, wood, and other commodities out of one part of the realm into another part, making their entries and taking cockets and making certificate to the next port or creek adjoining where the said officers be resident; � as to the transporting of wares or merchandise to or from beyond th seas to be utterly damned.

properties.title: Oreston
properties.head: Plymouth
properties.notes: Used but with lighters and such small vessels as doe convey such wares as are laden and unladen at [Plymouth] and at Saltash, � not mete otherwise to be used.

properties.title: Morewellham
properties.head: Plymouth
properties.notes: Used but with lighters and such small vessels as doe convey such wares as are laden and unladen at [Plymouth] and at Saltash, � not mete otherwise to be used.

properties.title: Chichester
properties.head: Chichester
properties.alternative_house: Recommendation to build a Custom House at Dell Quay in the parish of Apuldram, on land held of the Queen by Humphrey Ryman; and the merchants resorting thither will be much more eased, and the Queen's Majesty not be very greatly charged, because there are certain old walls of that same decayed, which may serve towards the making of the said Custom House.
properties.notes: More frequented and haunted with merchants and merchandises than in times past� more than any in Sussex except Rye. Of such breadth and depth that therein may harbour 500 great ships, without danger of weather or enemies. The bar, that before the putting down of the weirs was wont to annoy the ships there resorting, is so much abated within four years last past, as at the low water mark there the water is deeper than before, five feet, so that a ship of 100 tons may safely come over that bar without danage at three-quarter flood. From the bar to Itchenor is three miles, and from thence a barque of 40 tons may come into the Dell, being the quay of the port. In the said port or haven of Chichester there are four places where merchandize and goods be taken in and discharged, viz. Crakewode, West-deepe, Longwater, and in a place towards Thorney, which places have been so used time out of mind, but it is not mete they should be continued, but that all goods coming into the port of Chichester should be unladen at Dell Quay. The Customer of the port of Chichester hath dwelled at Rye, and appointed a deputy. [ORIGINAL RETURN FOR CHICHESTER & SUSSEX NOT YET LOCATED: Transcribed from https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=0VkMAQAAMAAJ&pg=RA1-PA210].
